He also disliked time travel because it robbed stories of their stakes. But then he loved alternate dimensions and retcons, which are arguably just as bad as time travel.
Greg's biggest writing sin (apart from his samey sarcastic asshole characters and general visual aphantasia) was his refusal to plan out stories because he claimed writing should be fun and surprising, and knowing where the story goes is boring. There's a telling quote that shows how Greg misunderstood plotting. He compared his style of writing to Orson Welles' performance on The Shadow radio drama. The obvious false equivalence is that Welles wasn't the writer, he was acting out a story that's been plotted out by someone else. Greg wasn't an actor, he was a writer, but he was more concerned with surprising himself with shocking twists and contrived cliffhangers than with telling a story.

I mean the system is made to be what i felt the essentials of a game were (action resolution, ways to make things challenging without just raising the TN, actual abilities outside of basic rolls) so the gameplay is pretty standard fare.

You make a roll to do anything that requires any level of skill or effort, like muscling through things, parkour, investigating something, resisting the effects of drugs or mind control, soothing or inciting the rage in a crowd. No matter the action, you roll a hand of poker dice (5d6). Theres 8 hand types worth between 0 and 5 points (and most are straightforward, like 1 pair being worth 1 point or 5 of a kind being worth 5). If you describe your action or use a helpful trait or item you can get up to 3 boons, each boon letting you reroll any number of dice one time

If its a normal action, you roll against a target number between 1 and 5; if it's a contested action you roll against the opponent. They tend to be good for about one go around, a playbook will always be that playbook and you end up fighting the system to play what you want to play unless you limit your character-building to the confines of that playbook.
